tool.name: Integron Finder
tool.description: is a program that detects integrons in DNA sequences
tool.command: integron_finder '$sequence' --cpu @THREADS@ --keep-tmp $local_max #if $type_replicon $type_replicon #end if #if $topology_file --topology-file '$topology_file' #end if $promoter_attI -dt $settings.attc_settings.dist_thresh --calin-threshold $settings.attc_settings.calin_threshold --max-attc-size $settings.attc_settings.max_attc_size --min-attc-size $settings.attc_settings.min_attc_size $settings.attc_settings.keep_palindromes #if $settings.attc_settings.covar_matrix --attc-model '$settings.attc_settings.covar_matrix' #end if $settings.protein_settings.no_proteins $settings.protein_settings.union_integrases $settings.protein_settings.func_annot $gbk $pdf && mv Results_Integron_Finder_* Results_Integron_Finder

param.name: sequence
param.label: Replicon file
param.help: Replicon can be entire chromosome, contif, PCR fragments...

validator.message: Integron Finder has problems with large multi FASTA files. Please assembly your sequences or split them up into files smaller 10.000 sequences.

param.validator: value is not None and value.metadata.sequences <= 10000

param.label: Thorough local detection
param.help: This option allows a more sensitive search. I will be slower (dependant on the number of hits) if integrons are found, but will be as fast if nothing is detected and will not increase the false positive rate.

param.name: type_replicon
param.label: Default replicons topology
param.help: Set the default topology for replicons, linear, circular (deault: no topology)

param.label: Select a topology file from your history
Search also for promoter and attI sites?
Genbank output?
param.help: Generate a GenBank file with the sequence annotated with the same annotations than .integrons file.

param.label: PDF output?
param.help: For each complete integron, a simple graphic of the region is depicted (in pdf format)

param.name: dist_thresh
param.label: Threshold for clustering (in base)
param.help: By default, to cluster an array of attC sites and an integron integrase, they must be less than 4 kb apart. You can here change this value.

param.name: calin_threshold
param.label: Threshold to filter CALIN
param.help: Keep 'CALIN' only if attC sites number >= calin-threshold

param.label: Keep palindromes with the highest evalue
param.help: For a given hit, if the palindromic version is found, don't remove the one with highest evalue

param.label: Just look for attC sites
param.help: When enabled, it does not annotate CDS and does not find integrase.

param.label: Use the union of the hits
param.help: Instead of taking intersection of hits from Phage_int profile (Tyr recombinases) and integron_integrase profile, use the union of the hits

tool.help:
How does it work ? ==================
- First, IntegronFinder annotates the DNA sequence's CDS with Prodigal.
- Second, IntegronFinder detects independently integron integrase and *attC* recombination sites. The Integron integrase is detected by using the intersection of two HMM profiles:
- one specific of tyrosine-recombinase (PF00589) - one specific of the integron integrase, near the patch III domain of tyrosine recombinases.
The *attC* recombination site is detected with a covariance model (CM), which models the secondary structure in addition to the few conserved sequence positions.
- Third, the results are integrated, and IntegronFinder distinguishes 3 types of elements:
- complete integron Integron with integron integrase nearby *attC* site(s) - In0 element Integron integrase only, without any *attC* site nearby - CALIN element Cluster of *attC* sites Lacking INtegrase nearby. A rule of thumb to avoid false positive is to filter out singleton of *attC* site.
IntegronFinder can also annotate gene cassettes (CDS nearby *attC* sites) using Resfams, a database of HMM profiles aiming at annotating antibiotic resistance genes. This database is provided but the user can add any other HMM profiles database of its own interest.
When available, IntegronFinder annotates the promoters and attI sites by pattern matching.
